newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: Singapore losing Japanese tourists to Hong Kong.
newsitem.headline: Singapore losing Japanese tourists to Hong Kong.

text.p: The number of Japanese tourists visiting Singapore fell in September and more Japanese women were being lured to Hong Kong by advertisements and magazine articles, the Sunday Times said.
The newspaper, quoting travel agents, said Japanese are also eager to visit Hong Kong before the British colony is handed back to China next year.
In September, Singapore had 103,705 Japanese visitors, down 7.0 percent from the same period a year earlier, and the downward trend has been visible since May, the paper said.

The director and general manager of NTA Travel, H. Uchino, was quoted as saying Japanese "office ladies", as single working women are known, opted to go to Hong Kong because the colony was perceived to be booming.
Japan Travel Bureau general manager Seizo Sakoda said his company saw a 10 percent drop in package tours for Japanese visitors this year compared to last.
Overall tourist arrivals in Singapore fell for the third straight month in September, according to data from the Singapore Tourist Promotion Board.

Total visitor arrivals for the first nine months of 1996 rose by 1.5 percent to 5.4 million from a year ago, but that compares to more than seven percent annual growth in 1993 and 1994 and 3.4 percent last year.
